title: Hail Mary
body:
Dear Riot,

Please refund all $ spent by the player, after you permanently ban them from your game. It is dirty money. You are better than to willingly take dirty money. I have faith in your humanitarianism.

Tootles!

Taking a players money after permanently banning them is dirty money because it is money gained by exploitation of people. Riot is fully aware that "misbehavior" is natural human behavior. Riot willingly accepts $ from people knowing that the person will be banned afterwards. Only a bully would take your money and then harm you, take your money and then harm you, take your money and then harm you, take your money and then harm you, take your money and then harm you, take your money and then harm you. (Riot goes on forever. The player stops/runs out of money.)

replies.body: Well you used the product so why give them a refund on a fucking rental anyways? Everything you "buy" is merely rented digital property. You dont own anything in the first place.

> [{quoted}](name=Telephone Booth,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=0006,timestamp=2018-12-18T05:13:24.378+0000)
>
> Well you used the product so why give them a refund on a fucking rental anyways? Everything you "buy" is merely rented digital property. You dont own anything in the first place.

Predatory lending. While not illegal, it is not an ethical practice. Thus, I am appealing to Riots conscience to practice ethical business.

> Predatory lending.

Predatory Lending is when a Lender gives you money that you're expected to give back with interest, then makes it harder for you do so so they can collect more interest.

That's *nothing* like what happens in League. 

In League, you give Riot money and say "I'll follow the rules", and in exchange Riot gives you a skin to use. There's no interest, there's no further payments needed, the only condition is "don't break the rules". There's nothing predatory about it, evidenced by the vast majority of people avoid losing their accounts at all.

-----

Somewhat ironically, the reason Riot *can't* give refunds to permabanned players is ethics. Someone who's tired of the game (or just needs a few hundred dollars back) would just get their account permabanned, then ask for a refund. The "ethical" reason to give back the money was someone couldn't behave in the community, the "ethical" player wouldn't abuse the system to get their money back.  

"Riot has millions!" doesn't hold up if everyone can ask for a few hundred back from them any time at all. And at some point they'd go bankrupt, because they have some of that RP money on paying employees, utilities, servers, buildings, advertising, etc.

> [{quoted}](name=DrCyanide,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=000600000001,timestamp=2018-12-18T14:39:18.123+0000)
>
> Predatory Lending is when a Lender gives you money that you're expected to give back with interest, then makes it harder for you do so so they can collect more interest.

There is more than one way to practice predatory lending. For example, giving a loan you are fully aware will not be able to be repaid. Another example is discrimination. 
  
> In League, you give Riot money and say "I'll follow the rules", and in exchange Riot gives you a skin to use. There's no interest, there's no further payments needed, the only condition is "don't break the rules". There's nothing predatory about it, evidenced by the vast majority of people avoid losing their accounts at all.

The rules are subject to change without notice. The rules (legislation, enforcement, and judgement) are at the sole discretion of Riot. Even the product being rented is at the sole discretion of Riot. As an analogy, Riot can lease a drill and change it to a pillow. The renter would have no recourse. EDIT: to take it even further, Riot could lease a drill. Then, destroy the drill completely. The renter would have no recourse.

> [{quoted}](name=mlm olo mlm,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=0006000000010000,timestamp=2018-12-18T15:06:01.226+0000)
>
> There is more than one way to practice predatory lending. For example, giving a loan you are fully aware will not be able to be repaid. Another example is discrimination. 

And neither of those hold up here, as 1) you don't need to repay, you just pay up front and 2) Riot holds everyone to the exact same standard, regardless of anything you could possibly discriminate on. 

> The rules are subject to change without notice. The rules (legislation, enforcement, and judgement) are at the sole discretion of Riot. 

They can be changed on a dime, yes. Just like they were when we moved to the tiered punishment system, and everyone with a chat restriction had it lifted instantly. 

While a sudden change of the rules would certainly be grounds for a Support Ticket to get unpunished, it's quite a stretch to say that because the rules *could* change that you *should* get a refund regardless of if they changed or not.

> Even the product being rented is at the sole discretion of Riot. As an analogy, Riot can lease a drill and change it to a pillow. The renter would have no recourse. EDIT: to take it even further, Riot could lease a drill. Then, destroy the drill completely. The renter would have no recourse.

And this would be an argument for refunds when a champion/skin gets reworked, but that's not what you're talking about in the OP.

Riots predatory lending scheme is providing content to people while knowing that the lessee is unable to uphold the contract. Then re-entering the same rental agreement, with the same lessee, after the lessee has already broken the previous rental agreement. All while offering a rental agreement that gives absolutely no rights to the lessee.

> [{quoted}](name=mlm olo mlm,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=000600000001000000000000,timestamp=2018-12-18T15:37:18.737+0000)

Then re-entering the same rental agreement, with the same lessee, after the lessee has already broken the previous rental agreement. All while offering a rental agreement that gives absolutely no rights to the lessee.

How does Riot know you'd be unable to uphold the contract? At every stage of punishment there's been people who turn it around and uphold the rules from there on out. There are people who have been permabanned banned before who turn around on the new account and do just fine, why should Riot assume one player is capable and the other is not? 

The right given to the lessee is that they can use the skins/champions while playing the game and following the rules. Presumably everyone who buys a skin thinks that's a right worth real money, otherwise they wouldn't pay for it. 

At some point "a fool and his money are quickly parted" has to come into play. The vast majority of players don't have issues with getting banned, an indication that the rules are fair. The few players who know they personally have issues with getting banned shouldn't keep buying skins *unless* they are fine with considering it like a temporary purchase in their individual situation.

> [{quoted}](name=DrCyanide,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=0006000000010000000000000001,timestamp=2018-12-18T16:08:35.803+0000)
>
> How does Riot know you'd be unable to uphold the contract? 

For starters, Riot makes all the terms of the contract while being able to modify any term, mid-lease, without notice, without reason.

Riot also knows about human behavior. They hired a psychologist to help design their systems. 

Also, there is the nature of Riots systems. They are actively searching for people to punish. Riot wouldn't have gone through all of the effort designing and constructing the systems if they didn't intend on using them. The intended use of such systems is to punish people. One of those punishments is permanently banning a player.

> At some point "a fool and his money are quickly parted" has to come into play.

Not a humanitarian way of thinking.

> [{quoted}](name=mlm olo mlm,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=00060000000100000000000000010000,timestamp=2018-12-18T19:50:56.378+0000)
>
> For starters, Riot makes all the terms of the contract while being able to modify any term, mid-lease, without notice, without reason.

That doesn't help predict why some people don't abide the rules while others do. It's the same rules for everyone. 

> Riot also knows about human behavior. They hired a psychologist to help design their systems. 

They hired a psychologist to make a system that would help most people reform. They did not hire a psychologist to predict which players would be incapable of reforming even after their account was banned.

> Also, there is the nature of Riots systems. They are actively searching for people to punish. Riot wouldn't have gone through all of the effort designing and constructing the systems if they didn't intend on using them. The intended use of such systems is to punish people. One of those punishments is permanently banning a player.

The only system that's actively searching for people to punish is the Scripting/Bot detection, with *maybe* the Leaver Buster system as a second. 

Everything else is passive, doing absolutely nothing until someone raises their hand and says there's a problem.

The effort was put in because there was too much of a delay between action and punishment before. If it took you 3 weeks after touching a stove top for you to feel the pain of burning that wouldn't be very helpful. Same thing with punishments, the closer they are to the event that triggered them the better they are at being a learning experience (rather than a punished out of the blue experience).

This learning experience works for the vast majority people. Very few keep behaving in a way that will get them punished over and over again enough to get a permaban. 

> Not a humanitarian way of thinking.

Everyone has to set a limit for how much help they can give to others and how much it will cost. If a humanitarian group could help a few thousand people for the same cost as helping one individual, which option do you think they'd choose? 

Riot takes the account away from the permabanned player so they'll stop playing. Trying to prevent them from making another account would be a very tedious and error prone task, so Riot is going to treat them like they're a brand new player or smurf of a player in good standing if they do come back. 

Now, Riot could spend the dev time trying to keep all permabanned players out forever and never let them make new accounts, preventing them from losing more money, coupling it with a system that stops you from buying RP if the computer says you're likely to get permabanned... or they could work on other things like fixing the client or improving Intentional Feeder detection. It's a numbers game, and more people would have an improved experience by Riot focusing on something else instead of preventing fools from spending money.

How do they know that someone's going to break the rules before they even do it? How do they know that someone is going to get themselves permanently banned before they even go through the punishment tiers?

Your argument doesn't make any sense, 'cause if Riot somehow had that level of prescience, they'd just cull the would-be-rulebreakers before they even get to Level 30.

> Then re-entering the same rental agreement, with the same lessee, after the lessee has already broken the previous rental agreement.

And how is Riot supposed to know whether or not the player will commit the same mistakes over and over and over again? Even if Riot could see for certain that Account XYZ is the same person who owned the now-permabanned Account ABC, how is Riot supposed to be able to determine whether or not the player will continue to break the rules?

You've heard the statement before, surely, that the degree of punishment tends to become an infinitesimally smaller fraction of the playerbase as it goes along. Only a handful of players ever get a chat restriction, and only a handful of them ever get another, and then a handful of those get a temp ban, and only a fraction of them get permabanned...

And then on, only a few of those permabanned players come back, and only a fraction of them continue breaking the rules, and only a fraction of a fraction of a fraction of those that _do_ so get themselves permabanned again.

And with millions upon millions of people playing League, Riot isn't going to be able to magically predetermine the intent of every single player, and every single account they make.

And this is ignoring whether or not the players actually spend more money on the game if they come back after a permanent ban.

At the end of the day, it's on the player themselves to make smart use of their own money. If they decide to spend money again after getting permabanned, and don't bother to reform, ultimately getting themselves banned again - that's their own damn fault.
They do practice ethical business. There's nothing unethical about denying service/refunds to people who don't want to follow the rules.

They don't take any money after permanently banning players.

After a player is permanently banned, they cannot enter the store. So, they cannot purchase additional RP.

So first off, there's no obligation on your end to purchase RP. You can progress through this game without having to spend a dime. You can buy the champs you want with free currency and obtain cosmetics without buying anything

Further, if they just give back money you spent on the game, there's no incentive to permaban anyone. You spent $100 on a permabanned account, here's your money back, now you can spend it on another.

This also drives incentive for players to return to the game after being permanently banned, which is not what they want. They do not want permabanned players returning to the game.

> [{quoted}](name=Periscope,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=bT9iu7Ea,comment-id=0010,timestamp=2018-12-18T20:35:12.010+0000)

> This also drives incentive for players to return to the game after being permanently banned, which is not what they want. They do not want permabanned players returning to the game.

I would disagree that there's no incentive to permaban anyone. The point of the permaban is to encourage behavioral change. Not to obtain money.

If there was a refund, there would be no incentive for players to improve their behavior after a permaban because there is no consequence to their action and would ultimately lead to a significantly more toxic gaming environment.

Your argument is that players naturally get banned, so it's not their fault they get banned. Riot just takes their money and eventually bans them.

A very, very small percentage of players get banned. They get banned because of decisions they consciously make. Riot will no longer take money from their account if a player gets banned. Riot just doesn't want their community to become a toxic cesspit for the health of the game and their reputation as a company. 

If you agree that you don't want the community to be toxic, and that toxic players should be punished, then you must concede that:

If you were banned, you probably paid a week or two of wages to the person that permanently banned your account or the person that designed the bot that banned your account. So you paid for the skins you enjoyed and got value out of, and you got value out of the punishment system!

That's value for money, you should be happy!
But... the players are meant to leave the game after a permaban. Not come back.

Society, in part, requires repressing certain natural urges for the benefit of humanity as a whole. Besides, setting up and following rules of society is (ironically) also part of our natural behaviour, as we are inherently social creatures.
From whichever side you want to view this, natural behaviour is no sufficient support for your argument.
